results.title: Law of the Journey
results.brief_description: Weiwei’s installation work Law of the Journey continues the artist’s exploration of the the global refugee crisis and its impact on the people involved. The work features a 196 foot inflatable sculpture, along with walls of photographs and moving image projections.

constellations_other.name: Seeking asylum
constellations_other.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

results.title: Lautrec
results.creator_credit: Geoff Dunbar, BFI and Dragon Productions
results.brief_description: Some of the more familiar Lautrec subjects are expertly animated in a graphic style. By the means of clever animation, Geoff Dunbar creates a personal study of this famous French artist.
results.description: Some of the more familiar Lautrec subjects are expertly animated in a graphic style. By the means of clever animation, Geoff Dunbar creates a personal study of this famous French artist.

results.title: Laurette
results.creator_credit: Pierre Lasry, Barrie Howells and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This is a portrayal of a young woman left alone to cope with family problems. Laurette is a young secretary, separated from her husband, with a daughter to bring up. Her thoughts, feelings and fears are shown. As she tries to make sense of the broken reality of her life, she must each day convince herself that life can go on while she provides a home for her child, that living as a “solo” parent is possible. (Awards: Washington)

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Wrong again. Angora love. Do detectives think
results.creator_credit: Leo McCarey, Lewis R. Foster, Hal Roach and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Three classic comic shorts from Laurel and Hardy. In “Wrong again” (20 mins. 1929), a comedy with a surrealistic edge, stable-hands Stan and Ollie respond to a millionaire’s offer of a reward for ‘Blue Boy’, a missing painting, by delivering ‘Blue Boy’ a horse. They find an instruction to leave ‘Blue Boy’ on the piano. In “Angora love” (20 mins. 1929), Stan and Ollie are adopted by a runaway goat. In “Do detectives think” (20 mins. 1927), the boys play inept detectives hired to guard a judge who is the target of an escaped convict.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: Wrong again. Angora love. Do detectives think

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Way out west. Big business
results.creator_credit: James W. Horne, Leo McCarey, Hal Roach, Stan Laurel, Hal Roach Studios and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Two comedies from slapstick team Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. “Way out West” - Stan and Ollie head out West as prospectors and when their partner Cy dies, they are entrusted to deliver the deed for valuable land to Cy’s daughter Mary. After all manner of mishaps, the pair are swindled by a crooked bar owner and his wife Lola. When Stan and Ollie realise the duplicity they have to steal the deed back, returning it to its rightful owner. Classic scenes include Stan being tickled into submission by Lola and eating his hat after losing a bet. “Way out west” is arguably one of Laurel and Hardy’s best-loved comedies, which can be viewed on this DVD in the colourised version or in original black and white. “Big business” - one of Laurel and Hardy’ last silent shorts has been identified as a masterful example of the genre. Laurel and Hardy are door-to-door Christmas tree salesmen who successfully offend potential customers, one of whom becomes enraged when the pair appears determined to harass him. As the feud escalates Laurel and Hardy commit a multitude of destructive acts, which results in the demolition of the owner’s house. He in turn unleashes a torrent of angst against the aforementioned tree and the hapless duo’s car, as a bemused crowd gather to watch.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: Way out west. Big business

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: The Chimp. That's my wife. Flying elephants
results.creator_credit: Frank Butler, James Parrott, Lloyd French, Walter Lundin and Hal Roach
results.brief_description: Three classic silent shorts from Laurel and Hardy with musical soundtrack. “The Chimp” (24 mins. 1932) Laid off by a bankrupt circus, Stan and Ollie are paid with assets by the ringmaster. Stan gets the flea circus, Ollie a trained chimp. Problems arise when they try to smuggle the pets into their apartment. In “That’s my wife” (17 mins. 1929), Ollie’s rich uncle visits assuming that he is happily married, but Ollie’s wife leaves him and Stan must masquerade as “the little woman”. “Flying elephants” (17 mins. 1927) sees Stan and Ollie play two cave men in this parody of ancient times where courtship procedures were handled with a club instead of a ring.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: The Chimp. That’s my wife. Flying elephants
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Butler, James Parrott, Lloyd French, Walter Lundin and Hal Roach

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Save the ship. Eve's love letters. White wings. A man about town
results.creator_credit: George Jeske, Ralph Ceder and Hal Roach
results.brief_description: Four classic silent shorts from Laurel and Hardy with musical soundtrack. In “Save the ship” (9 min. 1923), Stan is a hen-pecked husband living with his wife and her parents on a raft in the ocean. Catching his dinner proves to be a struggle that ends explosively. ‘White wings’ (9 mins. 1923) is a bizarre comedy that sees Stan as a street cleaner who accidentally walks off with a baby carriage instead of his cleaning carriage and is chased by a policeman. He returns as a resourceful butler in the 1925 comedy, “Eve’s love letter” (19 mins.) In “A man about town” (10 mins. 1923), Stan carries a single farce element to new heights of absurdity when he is told by a street-car conductor to “follow that girl” for his stop.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: Save the ship. Eve’s love letters. White wings. A man about town

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Country hospital. Them thar hills. Tit for tat
results.creator_credit: Charles Rogers, James Parrott, Hal Roach, Hal Roach Studios and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Three shorts from famed comic duo, Oliver Hardy and Stan Laurel. “County hospital”: When Oliver accidentally breaks his leg, Stanley visits him in hospital wreaking chaos on the hospital and his sick friend. Once ejected for the ensuing havoc they’ve created, Stan drives home perilously unaware that he is under the influence of a powerful sedative. “Them thar hills”: Heading up to the hills for a health jaunt to alleviate Ollie’s gout, Stan and Ollie drink from a stream tainted with bootleg liquor. As the two friends make lunch in an increasingly inebriated state, they encounter a married couple in need of fuel. Stan and Ollie accidentally get the wife drunk, causing the uptight husband to fly into a terrible rage. “Tit for tat”: Stan and Ollie buy an electrical goods store and fall into a bitter rivalry with the grocers across the way, each attempting to sabotage the other’s business. The owners of the grocery store are the same married couple that Ollie and Stan encountered on the mountain in “Them thar hills”.
results.title_for_label: Laurel and Hardy: Country hospital. Them thar hills. Tit for tat

results.title: Laurel and Hardy: Be big. Laughing gravy
results.creator_credit: James Parrott, James W. Horne, Hal Roach, Hal Roach Studios and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Four films from classic comedy duo Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. “Be big” - Laurel and Hardy desire to go to a raucous stag night, but their respective wives have planned a holiday to Atlantic City. Stan feigns illness to keep them in town for the night, but the plan unravels when their wives miss the train and discover their husbands on their way out for the evening. Bedlam ensues as the hapless pair face the full blast of their wives’ wrath. “Laughing gravy” - Stan and Ollie face eviction from their boarding house due to Ollie’s noisy dog, named Laughing gravy. Battling icy conditions, Ollie is forced to chase Laughing gravy through a storm whilst avoiding his irate landlord. When Stan gets a letter of inheritance, the condition is that he cut all ties with Ollie, and he is drawn into a real dilemma. “Los Calaveras” - combination of the Spanish versions of two shorts “Be big” and “Laughing gravy”, into a feature length film. “Les Carottiers” - combination of the French versions of two shorts “Be big” and “Laughing gravy”, into a feature length film. Immensely funny and inspired physical comedy.

results.title: Laurel & Hardy: Wrong again. Angora love. They go boom
results.creator_credit: James Parrott, Leo McCarey, Lewis R. Foster and Hal Roach
results.brief_description: Three classic comic shorts from Laurel and Hardy. In “Wrong again” (20 mins. 1929), a comedy with a surrealistic edge, stable-hands Stan and Ollie respond to a millionaire’s offer of a reward for ‘Blue Boy’, a missing painting, by delivering ‘Blue Boy’ a horse. They find an instruction to leave ‘Blue Boy’ on the piano. In “Angora love” (20 mins. 1929) Stan and Ollie are adopted by a runaway goat. In “They go boom” (20 mins. 1927) the boys try to cure Stan’s mysterious illness and throw the landlord into distress when the cure escalates into a disaster.
